text.content: Here's a collection of information to help you in your journey with LEGO® Education SPIKE™ Prime. Remember, you can also find more information in the Support section of LEGOeducation.com.

This block will play all the blocks that are attached to it. When pressing the Play Button in the bottom right corner of the screen, all the Play Blocks will start simultaneously.

**Example:**

code_stack.title: Gecko Block Help Example horizontalevents_whenProgramStarts
code_stack.xml: <xml xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" blockversion="10" ishorizontal="true"><variables></variables><block type="horizontalevents_whenProgramStarts" id="*(R|sO1ed;{?sv^KXpOp" x="114" y="375"><next><block type="horizontaldisplay_ledMatrix" id="`Ms}~j}@%%!03l1HU,px"><value name="MATRIX"><shadow type="horizontaldisplay_horizontal-3x3-matrix" id="LpdG1Dw@,_powIZBv=wC"><field name="field_horizontaldisplay_horizontal-3x3-matrix">777777777</field></shadow></value></block></next></block></xml>

text.content: This program uses the Play Block with the Light Block. When the program starts, the Light Block will play and turn the Light yellow.

This block is used to program the Color Sensor. It checks what color is in front of it. The block will play all the blocks that are attached to it if the Color Sensor sees the selected color. 

To change the color, press the white down arrow on the block and choose a color from the menu. 

**Example:**

code_stack.title: Gecko Block Help Example horizontalevents_whenColor
code_stack.xml: <xml xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" blockversion="10" ishorizontal="true"><variables></variables><block type="horizontalevents_whenColor" id="R:LE?9D;!~L*MMt,EOps" x="287" y="337"><value name="COLOR"><shadow type="horizontalevents_horizontal-color-sensor" id="8$kH6=B*t!Ffbq?3b@5$"><field name="field_horizontalevents_horizontal-color-sensor">3</field></shadow></value><next><block type="horizontalsound_playEffectSoundUntilDone" id="%IRoxG+uz^n{I?WIDtg*"><value name="SOUND"><shadow type="horizontalsound_horizontal-effect-sound" id="+2ZwRq.N#9;tuYs*l9bW"><field name="field_horizontalsound_horizontal-effect-sound">1</field></shadow></value></block></next></block></xml>

text.content: This program will play Sound Effect 1 whenever the Color Sensor sees blue.

This block programs the Force Sensor.  The Force Sensor Block if the Force Sensor is pressed or released. The block will play all the blocks that are attached to it if the Force Sensor. 

To change the setting, press the white down arrow on the block, and choose "pressed" or "released" from the menu. 

**Example:**

code_stack.title: Gecko Block Help Example horizontalevents_whenPressed
code_stack.xml: <xml xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" blockversion="10" ishorizontal="true"><variables></variables><block type="horizontalevents_whenPressed" id="b`~L^%$VbviA;FtnK=0`" x="355" y="333"><value name="OPTION"><shadow type="horizontalevents_horizontal-pressed" id="aVfPmiJdYxG3rHyF^WhB"><field name="field_horizontalevents_horizontal-pressed">released</field></shadow></value><next><block type="horizontalsound_playEffectSoundUntilDone" id="%IRoxG+uz^n{I?WIDtg*"><value name="SOUND"><shadow type="horizontalsound_horizontal-effect-sound" id="+2ZwRq.N#9;tuYs*l9bW"><field name="field_horizontalsound_horizontal-effect-sound">1</field></shadow></value></block></next></block></xml>

text.content: This program will play Sound Effect 1 whenever the Force Sensor goes from being pressed down to released.

This block programs the Distance Sensor. The Distance Sensor Block is used to check the current distance in front of the Distance Sensor. The block will play all the blocks attached to it if the Distance Sensor sees an object closer than the chosen distance. The Distance Sensor can see 200 cm (78 inches) ahead. The threshold for when this block will react on the object is indicated by the number in the block. The number is a percentage of the 0-200 cm (0-78 inches). 

To change the threshold, press the number in the block, then drag the slider left or right. 

**Example:**

code_stack.title: Gecko Block Help Example horizontalevents_whenCloserThan
code_stack.xml: <xml xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" blockversion="10" ishorizontal="true"><variables></variables><block type="horizontalevents_whenCloserThan" id="-txwc=tm:FD.Qe]a;^gK" x="162" y="306"><value name="DISTANCE"><shadow type="horizontalevents_horizontal-distance" id="flLjZsimeuX):c]Ngqxb"><field name="field_horizontalevents_horizontal-distance">50</field></shadow></value><next><block type="horizontalsound_playEffectSoundUntilDone" id="B}?:Rz=[1e:f@SQPD6wC"><value name="SOUND"><shadow type="horizontalsound_horizontal-effect-sound" id="h-(L{bZpDy9Y7`L:D|Io"><field name="field_horizontalsound_horizontal-effect-sound">1</field></shadow></value></block></next></block></xml>

text.content: This program will play Sound Effect 1 whenever the Distance Sensor sees an object closer than 50 % of the total range. The Distance Sensor's total range is 200cm.

This block programs the Built-in Gyro Sensor.  The Tilt Block is used to check the Built-in Gyro sensor on the LEGO® Technic™ Small Hub. The block will play all the blocks that are attached to it if the Hub is tilted to the chosen side. The block can check if the Hub is tilted forward, backward, left, right, any of those directions, or lying flat. 

To change the direction of the tilt, press the white down arrow on the block and select the corresponding arrow.

**Example:**

code_stack.title: Gecko Block Help Example horizontalevents_whenTilted
code_stack.xml: <xml xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" blockversion="10" ishorizontal="true"><variables></variables><block type="horizontalevents_whenTilted" id="c$piD9=[a9ZX0P~^5^jq" x="381" y="298"><value name="VALUE"><shadow type="horizontalevents_HorizontalTilted" id="%Ib0p3CsXkU_vRc{m6/+"><field name="field_horizontalevents_HorizontalTilted">2</field></shadow></value><next><block type="horizontalsound_playEffectSoundUntilDone" id="B}?:Rz=[1e:f@SQPD6wC"><value name="SOUND"><shadow type="horizontalsound_horizontal-effect-sound" id="h-(L{bZpDy9Y7`L:D|Io"><field name="field_horizontalsound_horizontal-effect-sound">1</field></shadow></value></block></next></block></xml>

text.content: This program will play Sound Effect 1 whenever the Hub is tilted forward.

This block is used to check the sound level in your microphone. The Loudness Block will play all the blocks that are attached to it if the sound level is louder than the set number or threshold. The threshold is a percentage of the maximum loudness your microphone can register. 

To change the threshold, press the white down arrow on the block, and drag the slider up or down. 

The Loudness Block uses the microphone in your device. You may need to give the Spike App permission to use the microphone in your device. 

**Example:**

code_stack.title: Gecko Block Help Example horizontalevents_whenLouderThan
code_stack.xml: <xml xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" blockversion="10" ishorizontal="true"><variables></variables><block type="horizontalevents_whenLouderThan" id="*S3KNQ~9~`+MN1wVFiRa" x="425" y="198"><value name="LOUDNESS"><shadow type="horizontalevents_horizontal-loudness" id="+@.FHf@p5Tnxh;!fs4Io"><field name="field_horizontalevents_horizontal-loudness">75</field></shadow></value><next><block type="horizontalsound_playEffectSoundUntilDone" id="B}?:Rz=[1e:f@SQPD6wC"><value name="SOUND"><shadow type="horizontalsound_horizontal-effect-sound" id="h-(L{bZpDy9Y7`L:D|Io"><field name="field_horizontalsound_horizontal-effect-sound">1</field></shadow></value></block></next></block></xml>

text.content: This program will play Sound Effect 1 whenever the sound level is louder than 75% of the maximum loudness your microphone can register.

This block lets you to play multiple programming stacks at once. The Receive Message Block must be used together with a Send Message in the same color to make it work. 

To change the color of the message, press the white down arrow on the block, then choose a color. 

**Example:**

code_stack.title: Gecko Block Help Example horizontalevents_whenBroadcast
code_stack.xml: <xml xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" blockversion="10" ishorizontal="true"><variables></variables><block type="horizontalevents_whenProgramStarts" id="h9A(I^}!kO3r9*d/6)6z" x="154" y="124"><next><block type="horizontalsound_playEffectSoundUntilDone" id="r#xDIuWwbt.5uZun(J5K"><value name="SOUND"><shadow type="horizontalsound_horizontal-effect-sound" id="}M,K3Mt:+pmr0qn[Cn3A"><field name="field_horizontalsound_horizontal-effect-sound">1</field></shadow></value><next><block type="horizontalevents_broadcast" id="J/Sr[T1IB)a/hBj:/XMa"><value name="CHOICE"><shadow type="horizontalevents_horizontal-broadcast-send" id="`gP~g^g5U0#qKLIBmylv"><field name="field_horizontalevents_horizontal-broadcast-send">blue</field></shadow></value><next><block type="horizontaldisplay_ledMatrix" id="I[{P]p4{_.U-0}6Ollt@"><value name="MATRIX"><shadow type="horizontaldisplay_horizontal-3x3-matrix" id="FhaE}(kM*dHK35Ulw4u7"><field name="field_horizontaldisplay_horizontal-3x3-matrix">777777777</field></shadow></value></block></next></block></next></block></next></block><block type="horizontalevents_whenBroadcast" id="y=M,/Ncdi?kkHU~$6}|_" x="279" y="241"><value name="CHOICE"><shadow type="horizontalevents_horizontal-broadcast-receive" id="2Pi]dCn7VBS%?zl(+#lG"><field name="field_horizontalevents_horizontal-broadcast-receive">blue</field></shadow></value><next><block type="horizontalsound_playEffectSoundUntilDone" id="8DZgkv=o@|N?iwgo0~:Y"><value name="SOUND"><shadow type="horizontalsound_horizontal-effect-sound" id="R.kBu:LF4-gYFCj@lz5Q"><field name="field_horizontalsound_horizontal-effect-sound">2</field></shadow></value></block></next></block></xml>

text.content:
This program contains two programming stacks. 

The upper stack starts when the Play Button is pressed. It plays Sound Effect 1 and then sends the blue message. Sending the blue message will start the lower programming stack, which will play Sound Effect 2 as the upper stack turns the Light yellow.

This block lets you play multiple programming stacks simultaneously. The Send Message block must be used together with a Received Message block. They also need to be the same color. 

To change the color of the message, press the white down arrow on the block and select a color. 

**Example:**

code_stack.title: Gecko Block Help Example horizontalevents_broadcast
code_stack.xml: <xml xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" blockversion="10" ishorizontal="true"><variables></variables><block type="horizontalevents_whenProgramStarts" id="h9A(I^}!kO3r9*d/6)6z" x="154" y="124"><next><block type="horizontalsound_playEffectSoundUntilDone" id="r#xDIuWwbt.5uZun(J5K"><value name="SOUND"><shadow type="horizontalsound_horizontal-effect-sound" id="}M,K3Mt:+pmr0qn[Cn3A"><field name="field_horizontalsound_horizontal-effect-sound">1</field></shadow></value><next><block type="horizontalevents_broadcast" id="J/Sr[T1IB)a/hBj:/XMa"><value name="CHOICE"><shadow type="horizontalevents_horizontal-broadcast-send" id="`gP~g^g5U0#qKLIBmylv"><field name="field_horizontalevents_horizontal-broadcast-send">blue</field></shadow></value><next><block type="horizontaldisplay_ledMatrix" id="I[{P]p4{_.U-0}6Ollt@"><value name="MATRIX"><shadow type="horizontaldisplay_horizontal-3x3-matrix" id="FhaE}(kM*dHK35Ulw4u7"><field name="field_horizontaldisplay_horizontal-3x3-matrix">777777777</field></shadow></value></block></next></block></next></block></next></block><block type="horizontalevents_whenBroadcast" id="y=M,/Ncdi?kkHU~$6}|_" x="279" y="241"><value name="CHOICE"><shadow type="horizontalevents_horizontal-broadcast-receive" id="2Pi]dCn7VBS%?zl(+#lG"><field name="field_horizontalevents_horizontal-broadcast-receive">blue</field></shadow></value><next><block type="horizontalsound_playEffectSoundUntilDone" id="8DZgkv=o@|N?iwgo0~:Y"><value name="SOUND"><shadow type="horizontalsound_horizontal-effect-sound" id="R.kBu:LF4-gYFCj@lz5Q"><field name="field_horizontalsound_horizontal-effect-sound">2</field></shadow></value></block></next></block></xml>

text.content:
This program contains two programming stacks. 

The upper stack starts when the Play Button is pressed. It plays Sound Effect 1 and then sends the blue message. Sending the blue message will start the lower programming stack, which will play Sound Effect 2 as the upper stack turns the Light yellow.

This block changes the speed of the motor(s) attached to the Hub. The speed can be set to 15%, 40%, 70% or 100%. The speed levels are indicated by the number of green bars. 

To use this block, place this block in front of the Run Motor Blocks (Clockwise or Counterclockwise). That will change the speed of the motor(s) from then on onwards. The Set Motor Speed Block will not change the speed of a running motor or start the motor. If the Set Motor Speed Block hasn’t been used, the default speed is 40%. 

To change the speed, press the white down arrow on the block, then press one of the 4 speed level buttons.

**Example**

code_stack.title: Gecko Block Help Example horizontalmotor_motorSetSpeed
code_stack.xml: <xml xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" blockversion="10" ishorizontal="true"><variables></variables><block type="horizontalevents_whenProgramStarts" id="e5@c[Up).t/P:;XAGo:H" x="87" y="271"><next><block type="horizontalmotor_motorTurnClockwiseRotations" id="ihC5BR0zUZ!5#QWN*1Fb"><value name="ROTATIONS"><shadow type="horizontalmotor_rotation-clockwise" id=",y@C1H3DFUIL*F6r;5yx"><field name="field_horizontalmotor_rotation-clockwise">1</field></shadow></value><next><block type="horizontalmotor_motorSetSpeed" id="0Xt1TQQdVt6LnRL[i*|;"><value name="SPEED"><shadow type="horizontalmotor_horizontal-motor-speed" id="Lo2D?1fA+NUaZ0sRO8}G"><field name="field_horizontalmotor_horizontal-motor-speed">100</field></shadow></value><next><block type="horizontalmotor_motorTurnCounterClockwiseRotations" id="IN8F.gx0nINdShg=~L;O"><value name="ROTATIONS"><shadow type="horizontalmotor_rotation-counter-clockwise" id="L|V^rQVywBRxd1CTtTQ0"><field name="field_horizontalmotor_rotation-counter-clockwise">1</field></shadow></value></block></next></block></next></block></next></block></xml>

text.content: This program will turn the Motor clockwise for one rotation using the default speed (40%). Then, the program will turn the motor counterclockwise for one rotation at 100% speed.

This block will make the Motor(s) attached to the Hub run counterclockwise. The speed can be changed using the Motor Speed Block. 

To change how many rotations the motor should run, open the block menu by pressing the white down arrow on the block. Use the plus (+) and minus (-) buttons to increase or decrease the number of full rotations. Use the dial to increase or decrease by quarter (0.25) rotations.

**Example**

code_stack.title: Gecko Block Help Example horizontalmotor_motorTurnCounterClockwiseRotations
code_stack.xml: <xml xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" blockversion="10" ishorizontal="true"><variables></variables><block type="horizontalevents_whenProgramStarts" id="e5@c[Up).t/P:;XAGo:H" x="87" y="271"><next><block type="horizontalmotor_motorTurnCounterClockwiseRotations" id="cAEZW/vPOoyoe%]I*6Pm"><value name="ROTATIONS"><shadow type="horizontalmotor_rotation-counter-clockwise" id="Qx4VG;^8?3+$EPDdtmmB"><field name="field_horizontalmotor_rotation-counter-clockwise">2.5</field></shadow></value></block></next></block></xml>

text.content: This program will turn the Motor counterclockwise for 2.5 rotations.

This block will make the Motor(s) attached to the Hub run clockwise. The speed can be changed using the Motor Speed Block. 

To change how many rotations the motor should run, open the block menu by pressing the white down arrow. Use the plus (+) and minus (-) buttons to increase or decrease the number of full rotations. Use the dial to increase or decrease by a quarter (0.25) rotation. 

**Example**

code_stack.title: Gecko Block Help Example horizontalmotor_motorTurnClockwiseRotations
code_stack.xml: <xml xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" blockversion="10" ishorizontal="true"><variables></variables><block type="horizontalevents_whenProgramStarts" id="e5@c[Up).t/P:;XAGo:H" x="87" y="271"><next><block type="horizontalmotor_motorTurnClockwiseRotations" id="fBT]4/5,BekylyW!=h,y"><value name="ROTATIONS"><shadow type="horizontalmotor_rotation-clockwise" id="L3lV!`%x^m4`YyDjXMsu"><field name="field_horizontalmotor_rotation-clockwise">2.5</field></shadow></value></block></next></block></xml>

text.content: This program will turn the Motor clockwise for 2.5 rotations.

This block will stop all running motors.

**Example**

code_stack.title: Gecko Block Help Example horizontalmotor_motorStop
code_stack.xml: <xml xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" blockversion="10" ishorizontal="true"><variables></variables><block type="horizontalevents_whenProgramStarts" id="e5@c[Up).t/P:;XAGo:H" x="96" y="151"><next><block type="horizontalmotor_motorTurnClockwiseRotations" id="P0L=UD!-Y}zb.}(!GYD{"><value name="ROTATIONS"><shadow type="horizontalmotor_rotation-clockwise" id="^0vaU]ax[|-FQMDL8o)d"><field name="field_horizontalmotor_rotation-clockwise">99</field></shadow></value></block></next></block><block type="horizontalevents_whenColor" id=".m}AY|IGZK7(jSZ?R([X" x="99" y="269"><value name="COLOR"><shadow type="horizontalevents_horizontal-color-sensor" id=";3!4;UVAfi,9ZbYyGe#F"><field name="field_horizontalevents_horizontal-color-sensor">9</field></shadow></value><next><block type="horizontalmotor_motorStop" id=";uglD-819Cji93W:/qIf"></block></next></block></xml>

text.content:
This program contains two programming stacks. 

The upper stack will start the Motor and make it run for 99 rotations when the program starts. The lower stack checks If the Color Sensor sees a red color. If that happens, the Motor will be told to stop immediately. 

When trying this program, be sure to press the Play Button in the bottom right corner to start both programming stacks.

This block programs the 3x3 Light Matrix. To create your own pattern for the 3x3 Light Matrix, open the block menu by pressing the white down arrow.  Now use the color selector on the right to select a color and draw the pixels in that color on the big 3x3 grid. The small 3x3 grid on the bottom left will clear the pattern. The small 3x3 grid on the right  will set all pixels to the selected color. 

The 3x3 Light Block waits 0.2 seconds before progressing to the next block.

**Example:**

code_stack.title: Gecko Block Help Example horizontaldisplay_ledMatrix
code_stack.xml: <xml xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" blockversion="10" ishorizontal="true"><variables></variables><block type="horizontalevents_whenProgramStarts" id="dLlDSD*;UL%qZ$Y+c3U@" x="138" y="244"><next><block type="horizontaldisplay_ledMatrix" id="o/c_%Ajwt^G;bwth?w-X"><value name="MATRIX"><shadow type="horizontaldisplay_horizontal-3x3-matrix" id="fILt|,[kBWGCI$@m4ju["><field name="field_horizontaldisplay_horizontal-3x3-matrix">000040000</field></shadow></value><next><block type="horizontaldisplay_ledMatrix" id="!b7^/7NUf@$lQLX)IlrY"><value name="MATRIX"><shadow type="horizontaldisplay_horizontal-3x3-matrix" id="jWJqj)!dBYFcKE%/$X{X"><field name="field_horizontaldisplay_horizontal-3x3-matrix">040444040</field></shadow></value><next><block type="horizontaldisplay_ledMatrix" id="AWbM{q[5*}t7/ZiG{3W}"><value name="MATRIX"><shadow type="horizontaldisplay_horizontal-3x3-matrix" id="Bn%ke%)aL*Gk^:U}Kbv,"><field name="field_horizontaldisplay_horizontal-3x3-matrix">444444444</field></shadow></value></block></next></block></next></block></next></block></xml>

text.content: This program makes the 3x3 Light Matrix quickly change between three different patterns. The time between each new pattern is 0.2 seconds.

This block will make the 3x3 Light Matrix light up in a random color. The block waits 0.2 seconds before progressing to the next block.

**Example:**

code_stack.title: Gecko Block Help Example horizontaldisplay_ledMatrixRandom
code_stack.xml: <xml xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" blockversion="10" ishorizontal="true"><variables></variables><block type="horizontalevents_whenProgramStarts" id="dLlDSD*;UL%qZ$Y+c3U@" x="138" y="244"><next><block type="control_forever" id="2iZjC5uCD7D]JLsrcD.|"><statement name="SUBSTACK"><block type="horizontaldisplay_ledMatrixRandom" id="K6;:Nh:DGOT.l,lkrg]}"></block></statement></block></next></block></xml>

text.content: This program makes the 3x3 Light Matrix light up in new random color forever. The time between each color change is 0.2 seconds.

This block programs the 5x5 Light Matrix. To create your own pattern for the 5x5 Light Matrix, open the block menu by pressing the white down arrow. Use the brightness selection on the right to select a brightness and draw the pixels in that color on the big 5x5 grid. The small 3x3 grid on the bottom left will clear the pattern. The small 5x5 grid on the right will set all pixels to the selected brightness. 

The 5x5 Light Block waits 0.2 seconds before progressing to the next block.

**Example:**

This block will make the 5x5 Light Matrix light up in a random pattern where each pixel is a random brightness. The block waits 0.2 seconds before moving to the next block.

**Example:**

This block will play an animal sound.  Select from 8 different animal sounds.  

To choose a sound, press the white down arrow on the block, then pick a number in the menu. Choosing the dice will pick a new random animal sound every time the block plays. 

**Example:**

This block will play a sound effect. There are 8 effects to pick from. 

To choose the sound effect press the white down arrow on the block, then pick a number in the block menu. Choosing the dice will pick a new random sound effect every time the block plays. 

**Example:**

This block will play a music through the device. 

To choose what track is played, press the white down arrow on the block and select a number in the menu. Choosing the dice will pick a new random music track every time the block plays.

**Example:**

text.content: This program will play music track number 5.

This block allows you to record your own sound. It enables you to record your own sound and save it as a new block to use in your program. 

To make a new recording, press Record Sound to open the Record Sound menu. Press the record button in the middle to start the recording. When you are finished press the stop button, and the checkmark button to save the recording. Your recording will save as a new block

To delete or edit the recording, right click the block in the block palette. On a touch device hold down on the block to access the same menu. If the recorded sound block is on the programming canvas, it cannot be deleted. 

**Example:**

text.content:
This program contains two programming stacks. 

The upper programming stack makes the motor(s) run 1 rotation forever when the program starts. The lower programming stack will when the Color Sensor sees a red brick. 

When trying this program, be sure to press the Play Button in the bottom right corner of the programming canvas to start both programming stacks.

This block changes the speed of moving a Driving Base. A Driving Base is a LEGO robot that drives with two identical motors. The speed levels are indicated by the number of green bars. The speed can be set to 15%, 40%, 70% or 100%. 

To use this block, place this block in front of the other Movement Blocks. It will change the speed of the Driving Base from then on onwards. The Set Movement Speed Block will not change the speed of a running Motor or start the Motor. 

To change the speed, press the white down arrow on the block, then press one of the speed level buttons.
**Example:**

code_stack.title: Gecko Block Help Example horizontalmove_moveSetSpeed
code_stack.xml: <xml xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" blockversion="11" ishorizontal="true"><variables></variables><block type="horizontalevents_whenProgramStarts" id="!B@`CJ1)FPTSBYZfm93c" x="273" y="224"><next><block type="horizontalmove_moveTurnCounterClockwiseRotations" id="Ti-{{!D,~OI+)%xrDW(Q"><value name="ROTATIONS"><shadow type="horizontalmove_horizontal-move-positive-number" id="9K0?P~umWV%@tnQ#D}@?"><field name="field_horizontalmove_horizontal-move-positive-number">1</field></shadow></value><next><block type="horizontalmove_moveSetSpeed" id="e3W7qry.Q*[G1_3`.a.M"><value name="SPEED"><shadow type="horizontalmove_horizontal-move-speed" id="8aYsfNXaeUkkiKbbw4|y"><field name="field_horizontalmove_horizontal-move-speed">100</field></shadow></value><next><block type="horizontalmove_moveForward" id="bDEW9`|^ibdU3H-I%Kqs"><value name="ROTATIONS"><shadow type="horizontalmove_horizontal-move-positive-number" id="C$jM4h#c9NCa*+YL$:an"><field name="field_horizontalmove_horizontal-move-positive-number">1</field></shadow></value></block></next></block></next></block></next></block></xml>

text.content: This program will turn a Driving Base 90 degrees counterclockwise using the default speed (40%). Then, it will  move the Driving Base 1 wheel-rotation forward at 100% speed.

This block moves a Driving Base forward a number of wheel rotations. A Driving Base is a LEGO robot that drives with two identical motors.

To change the number of wheel rotations, press the number on the block. Entering 1 into the block will make each wheel turn 1 full rotation.
**Example:**

code_stack.title: Gecko Block Help Example horizontalmove_moveForward
code_stack.xml: <xml xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" blockversion="11" ishorizontal="true"><variables></variables><block type="horizontalevents_whenProgramStarts" id=";zXbre+LbckN?n:nqB?Z" x="621" y="87"><next><block type="horizontalmove_moveForward" id="hV|tL=jqM3kkF.;Dx14B"><value name="ROTATIONS"><shadow type="horizontalmove_horizontal-move-positive-number" id="FU)D,/5[v|-]1#Xak}L{"><field name="field_horizontalmove_horizontal-move-positive-number">2</field></shadow></value></block></next></block></xml>

text.content: This program will move the Driving Base forward two-wheel rotations.

This block moves a Driving Base backwards. A Driving Base is a LEGO robot that drives with two identical motors. 

To change the number of wheel rotations, press the number on the block. Putting 1 into the block will make each wheel turn 1 full rotation.
**Example:**

code_stack.title: Gecko Block Help Example horizontalmove_moveBackward
code_stack.xml: <xml xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" blockversion="11" ishorizontal="true"><variables></variables><block type="horizontalevents_whenProgramStarts" id=";zXbre+LbckN?n:nqB?Z" x="621" y="87"><next><block type="horizontalmove_moveBackward" id="My]gC:5m]u7k;7}Fpa.y"><value name="ROTATIONS"><shadow type="horizontalmove_horizontal-move-positive-number" id="}7d6Ocu`^7aFw1n@Xo3z"><field name="field_horizontalmove_horizontal-move-positive-number">2</field></shadow></value></block></next></block></xml>

text.content: This program will move the Driving Base backwards 2 wheel rotations.

This block turns a Driving Base counterclockwise. A Driving Base is a LEGO robot that drives with two identical motors.  

To change how much the Driving Base should turn, press the number on the block. Typing 1 into the block will make a Driving Base turn 90 degrees.

Changing the size of the wheels or the distance between the wheels will change the number of degrees this block will turn.  

**Example:**

code_stack.title: Gecko Block Help Example horizontalmove_moveTurnCounterClockwiseRotations
code_stack.xml: <xml xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" blockversion="11" ishorizontal="true"><variables></variables><block type="horizontalevents_whenProgramStarts" id=";zXbre+LbckN?n:nqB?Z" x="621" y="87"><next><block type="horizontalmove_moveTurnCounterClockwiseRotations" id="|6|MA~l9v8yKqdMLo`54"><value name="ROTATIONS"><shadow type="horizontalmove_horizontal-move-positive-number" id=";pJ]Ox=-0^-zHVhFpeF2"><field name="field_horizontalmove_horizontal-move-positive-number">4</field></shadow></value></block></next></block></xml>

text.content: This program will turn the Driving Base 360 degrees counterclockwise.

This block turns a Driving Base clockwise. A Driving Base is a LEGO robot that drives with two identical motors.

To change how much the Driving Base should turn, press the number on the block. Add the number of rotations that the Driving Base will move.

Changing the size of the wheels or the distance between the wheels will change the number of degrees this block will turn.  

**Example:**

text.content: This program will make the Driving Base turn 360 degrees clockwise.

text.content:
This program contains two programming stacks. 

The upper programming stack starts moving a Driving Base forward 99-wheel rotations when the program starts. The lower programming stack checks if the Hub is tilted in any direction. If that happens, it will stop the Driving Base.

When trying this program, be sure to press the Play Button in the bottom right corner of the programming canvas to start both programming stacks.

This block displays text in the display window. Press the full-screen button in the top left to make the text full screen.

To change the text, press the text field in the block and start typing a new text.
**Example:**

This block displays an image in the display window. Press the full-screen button in the top left to make the image full screen. 

To change the image, press the white down arrow on the block, then press the image you want to display. Choosing the dice will pick a random image every time the block plays.

This block changes how an image or text is displayed. The image and text can be displayed full screen or in a smaller window on the programming canvas. 

To change the display format, press the white down arrow on the block, and then pick either full screen (two green arrows) or window view from the menu (one green arrow).

This program contains two programming stacks. 

The upper stack in this program will clear the bar graph when the program starts. The lower stack will add increase the red bar by 1 every time the Color Sensor sees a red brick.

This block changes how the Bar Graph is displayed. The Bar Graph can be displayed full screen or in a smaller window on the programming canvas.

text.content:
This program contains two programming stacks. 

The upper stack of this program will make the Bar Graph full screen. The lower stack of this program will increase the magenta bar by 1 every time the Hub is tilted right.
Motor Blocks either make the motors run or get information from the motors. The *Motor Blocks* category contains the most common Motor Blocks.

text.content:
This block will run one or more motors clockwise or counterclockwise for a specified number of rotations, seconds, or degrees. 

The motor speed is set by the Set Speed Block. The default speed is 75%. 

“Stall detection” is enabled by default. See the *Turn Stall Detection On/Off Block* for more information.

code_stack.title: Gecko Block Help flippermotor_motorGoDirectionToPosition

text.content:
This block sets one or more motors to a speciﬁed position. The motor can be set to run clockwise, counterclockwise, or to take the shortest path to the specified position. The position ranges from 0 to 359 degrees.

The motor speed is set by the Set Speed Block. The default speed is 75%.

“Stall detection” is enabled by default. See the Turn Stall Detection On/Off Block for more information.

text.content:
This block will run one or more motors clockwise or counterclockwise forever. The motor speed is set by the Set Speed Block. The default speed is 75%.

“Stall detection” is enabled by default. See the Turn Stall Detection On/Off Block for more information.

text.content: This block stops one or more motors from running. The motor will brake so that it quickly comes to a complete stop. The motor will not hold its position once it has stopped.

text.content: This block sets the speed of one or more motors. The speed range is -100 to 100. Negative values will reverse the direction of the motor. If the speed hasn't been specified, the default value is 75%.

Movement Blocks enable you to run two motors in a synchronized motion. They're primarily used to move Driving Bases around. Only motors of the same type (e.g., two Medium Motors) can be synchronized.

Higher steering values (i.e., +99 and -99) will make the arc path of the Driving Base sharper. Use a value of “0” to drive in a straight line. Using the values 100 and -100 will make the Driving Base pivot on itself.

Use a value of “0” to drive in a straight line. Using the values 100 and -100 will make the Driving Base pivot on itself.

Event Blocks are comprised entirely of Hat Blocks, meaning that they're always the first block in a programming stack and other blocks can only be attached under them. Hat Blocks are necessary to start a programming stack and will be triggered when a specified event occurs.

code_stack.title: Gecko Block Help flipperevents_whenProgramStarts

text.content: This block plays all of the blocks attached to it, sequentially from top to bottom, when the program starts. The program can be started by clicking the Play Button or, when not in Streaming Mode, by pressing the Center Button on the Hub.

code_stack.title: Gecko Block Help flipperevents_whenColor

text.content:
This block plays all of the blocks attached to it when the Color Sensor detects a speciﬁed color. The detectable colors are:
  • (0) Black
  • (1) Violet
  • (3) Blue
  • (4) Light Blue
  • (5) Green
  • (7) Yellow
  • (9) Red
  • (10) White
  • (-1) no color
This block will only trigger when it detects the speciﬁed color. This means that the block won't re-trigger if the detected color remains unchanged.

code_stack.title: Gecko Block Help flipperevents_whenPressed

text.content:
This block plays all of the blocks attached to it when the Force Sensor is pressed, hard-pressed, released, or when it detects any change in the pressure that's being applied.

This block will only trigger at the speciﬁed event. This means that the block won't re-trigger if the pressure on the Force Sensor remains unchanged.

This block plays all of the blocks attached to it when the Distance Sensor detects that an object is closer than or further than the specified distance.

This block will only trigger at the speciﬁed event. This means that the block won't re-trigger if the distance remains unchanged.

code_stack.title: Gecko Block Help flipperevents_whenTilted

text.content:
This block plays all of the blocks attached to it when the Hub is tilted in the specified direction starting from a flat, button(s) up position.

The block will only trigger at the event of the Hub being tilted. That means that it won't trigger again as long as the Hub isn't tilted in a new direction.

code_stack.title: Gecko Block Help flipperevents_whenOrientation

text.content:
This block plays all of the blocks attached to it when the Hub is placed in the specified orientation. The possible orientations are:
  • (1) Front
  • (2) Back
  • (3) Top
  • (4) Bottom
  • (5) Left side
  • (6) Right side
This block will only trigger at the speciﬁed event. This means that the block won't re-trigger if the orientation of the Hub remains unchanged.

code_stack.title: Gecko Block Help flipperevents_whenGesture

text.content:
This block plays all of the blocks attached to it when the Hub is:
  • (1) Shaking
  • (2) Tapped
  • (3) Falling
This block will only trigger at the start of the speciﬁed event. This means that the block won't re-trigger if the movement of the Hub remains unchanged.

code_stack.title: Gecko Block Help flipperevents_whenButton

text.content:
This block plays all of the blocks attached to it when the Left or Right Buttons are pressed or released.

This block will only trigger at the speciﬁed event. This means that the block won't re-trigger as long as the state of the Buttons remains unchanged.

code_stack.title: Gecko Block Help flipperevents_whenGreaterThan

text.content: This block plays all of the blocks attached to it when either the loudness or timer gets above a specified value. The "loudness" is the volume measured by your device's internal microphone. The highest value is "100." The lowest value is "0." The "timer" is a constantly running clock. It starts from "0" when the program starts. It can be reset using the Reset Timer Block.

code_stack.title: Gecko Block Help flipperevents_whenCondition

text.content:

The Control Blocks category contains all of the blocks that can modify the linear flow of block execution, such as “wait for” structures, loops, and conditions.

code_stack.title: Gecko Block Help control_forever vertical

text.content:
All of the blocks held inside this block will loop forever.

The only way to stop the loop is to interrupt the program by pressing the Stop Button, or by using the Stop All Block.

code_stack.title: Gecko Block Help control_if
code_stack.xml: <xml xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" blockversion="10" ishorizontal="false"><variables></variables><block type="control_if" id="U^uYG%:1P}3bhZGfvG:Z" x="-109" y="119"></block></xml>

text.content:
This block will check whether the specified boolean condition is true.

If the condition is true, all of the blocks held inside it will play. If the condition is false, the blocks will be ignored.

text.content:
This block will check whether the specified boolean condition is true.

If the condition is true, the blocks held inside the first space will play and the stack will continue. If the condition is false, the blocks inside the second space will play.

text.content: All of the blocks held inside this block will loop until the speciﬁed boolean condition is true. When the specified condition becomes true, blocks beneath it will play.

code_stack.title: Gecko Block Help flippersensors_orientationAxis
code_stack.xml: <xml xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" blockversion="10" ishorizontal="false"><variables></variables><block type="flippersensors_orientationAxis" id=";utyfq1il);p@Du7HrtG" x="-61" y="97"><field name="AXIS">pitch</field></block></xml>

text.content:
This block reports the Hub's pitch, roll, or yaw angle. Pitch, roll, and yaw are terms commonly used to describe an airplane's movement through air but they can apply to any object rotating in all three dimensions. When looking at an airplane:
  • The pitch angle refers to the airplane's nose going up or down.
  • The roll angle refers to the airplane's wings going up or down.
  • The yaw angle refers to the direction of the airplane compared to the ground.

code_stack.title: Gecko Block Help flippersensors_resetYaw

For example, if “my variable” contains “LEGO,” using the block shown above will change the value to “1.”

text.content:
The available Weather Blocks are based on forecasts, not current values. Students can play around with forecasts up to 240 hours ahead of the current time.

Weather Blocks will only work when you’re online because they fetch real time data.

This block returns the atmospheric pressure, in hectopascal (hPa), at the set forecast location.

text.content:
This block reports the wind direction at the set forecast location. The direction is given as a string:
  • "N" for north
  • "NE" for northeast
  • "E" for east
  • "SE" for southeast
  • "S" for south
  • "SW" for southwest
  • "W" for west
  • "NW" for northwest

This block will run one or more motors clockwise or counterclockwise for a specified number of rotations, seconds, or degrees at a speed specified as a percentage or in revolutions per minute.

“Stall detection” is enabled by default. See the Turn Stall Detection On/Off Block for more information.

This block runs one or more motors to a relative position at a specified speed. Unlike the absolute position that's used in the Go to Position Block, the relative position has no range limit and can be preset with the Set Relative Motor Position to 0 Block.

'Stall detection' is enabled by default See the Turn Stall Detection On/Off Block for more information.

This block will run one or more motors at a specified percentage of power forever. When running a motor according to speed, the power of the motor is regulated in order to maintain the speciﬁed speed.

“Stall detection” is enabled by default. See the Turn Stall Detection On/Off Block for more information.

text.content: This block returns, as a percentage, the power level currently being used on the specified motor.

code_stack.title: Gecko Block Help flippermoremotor_motorSetStopMethod
code_stack.xml: <xml xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" blockversion="10" ishorizontal="false"><variables></variables><block type="flippermoremotor_motorSetStopMethod" id=".~fsBR{*-=+@0k%PkQl;" x="-112" y="57"><field name="STOP">1</field><value name="PORT"><shadow type="flippermoremotor_multiple-port-selector" id="0~#Q_yVM{5hvqoM[s_i-"><field name="field_flippermoremotor_multiple-port-selector">A</field></shadow></value></block></xml>

text.content:
This block specifies how the motor will stop when using a Motor Block with a specified duration, or the Stop Motor Block. The motor can stop in three different ways:
  • Brake: the default method in which the motor uses power to brake when stopping and applies friction to the motor afterward
  • Hold position: the motor uses power to brake and actively moves the motor back to the position in which it stopped, if it is forced away from it
  • Float: the power to the motor is cut when stopping

code_stack.title: Gecko Block Help flippermoremotor_motorSetStallDetection
code_stack.xml: <xml xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" blockversion="10" ishorizontal="false"><variables></variables><block type="flippermoremotor_motorSetStallDetection" id="[IzSdl,Z{Ab]IlLYl[gS" x="-112" y="63"><field name="ENABLED">true</field><value name="PORT"><shadow type="flippermoremotor_multiple-port-selector" id="S`-XkoCjLv`w$Kep5=4E"><field name="field_flippermoremotor_multiple-port-selector">A</field></shadow></value></block></xml>

text.content:
This block will disable stall detection on the Motor and Movement Blocks. With stall detection turned off, the motors will keep trying to complete their command even when they're physically stopped, which will halt the rest of the program.

By default, all motor and movement commands will detect when a motor has stalled. A motor stall means that something has physically prevented the motor from completing its command. When stalling occurs, the program will continue to the next block in the programming stack.

This block starts moving a Driving Base forever at the power that's been speciﬁed for each motor. The ﬁrst specified value sets the power of the left motor, and the second specified value sets the power of the right motor.
  • Running the motors with power will unlike running the motors with speed, not regulate the speed of the motors. Use power for robots that should be regulated on other inputs than speed, such as a line-following robot or a self-balancing-robot.

text.content:
This block starts moving a Driving Base forward forever using a steering value and a specified percentage of power.
  • Higher steering values (i.e., +99 and -99) will make the arc path of the Driving Base sharper. Use a value of “0” to drive straight forward. Using the values 100 and -100 will make the Driving Base pivot on itself.
  • Running the motors with power will unlike running the motors with speed, not regulate the speed of the motors. Use power for robots that should be regulated on other inputs than speed, such as a line-following robot or a self-balancing-robot.

The Scratch programming language is made up of different types of blocks, each represented by a different shape.
Hat Blocks are used to start a program. They have a rounded top so that other blocks can only be attached under them.
Stack Blocks perform the main commands in a program. They're the blocks that can make the motors move and the lights light up!
C Blocks are C-shaped blocks. They're placed between the beginning and the end of the loop or check whether a condition is “true.” All of the C Blocks can be found in the Control category.
Reporter Blocks hold values, which can be a number or a string. Among other things, they can hold a sensor reading or store the value of a variable.
Boolean Blocks are conditions that can either be true or false. They're used together with C Blocks to form the logic of a program.

Cap Blocks are used to end scripts. They're shaped with a notch at the top and a ﬂat bottom so that you can't place any blocks below them. There are two Cap Blocks, both of which can be found in the Control category.
A programming stack is a number of blocks that have been put together.

We use cookies or similar technologies on our digital applications.
-------------------------------------------------------------------

Cookies and similar technologies are small data files that your browser or app set on your computer or device. When sent to our servers, this information can help us deliver a more user-friendly and properly functioning service.

Our applications collect some information (e.g. information on IP addresses, browsers, operating systems, date stamps and time stamps). This information will not be linked to any other information we collect about you unless you have consented to it. But not every cookie is the same. For a list of the categories of cookies we use, see below. 

The cookies and similar technologies we use fall into two categories.

Required Cookies: These cookies and similar technologies are required to enable core app functionality and are therefore always enabled. This category includes your IP address, selected country and language and, in the event an error occurs, your usage of the app when such error occurs. When such information is collected, we will not ask for your consent, because we have a legitimate purpose – to ensure core functionality. Please note that you can opt-out of the other categories, but you cannot opt-out from sending required information. 

Tracking of Non-Personal Information: The tracking of this information is optional and allows us to track your usage of our app for statistical purposes to optimize your experience. We only use this information where the purpose is considered legitimate and does not require consent. The information that we collect is limited to anonymous and aggregated information which does not include any personally identifiable information. We will not ask to get your permission to collect this information, however you can at any time opt out by clicking on the settings tab and then selecting the opt out feature.

We use cookies or similar technologies on our digital applications.
-------------------------------------------------------------------

We use cookies or similar technologies on our digital applications.

Cookies and similar technologies are small data files that your browser or app sets on your computer or device. When sent to our servers, this information can help us deliver a properly functioning service – for example, reporting errors when they occur.

Our applications collect some information (e.g. information on IP addresses, browsers, operating systems, date stamps and time stamps). This information will not be linked to any other information we collect about you unless you have consented to it, and our use of such information will be limited to facilitating online communication or processes that are strictly necessary for functionality (collectively, “Strictly Necessary Cookies”).

Strictly Necessary Cookies: These are required to enable core app functionality and are therefore always enabled. This category includes your IP address, selected country and language and, in the event an error occurs, this information will be also sent to our servers to help us resolve the error. When such information is collected, we will not ask for your consent, because we have a legitimate purpose – to ensure core functionality.
